skill.name: chipsec
skill.description: Static analysis of UEFI/BIOS firmware dumps using Intel's chipsec framework. Decode firmware structure, detect known malware and rootkits (LoJax, ThinkPwn, HackingTeam, MosaicRegressor), generate EFI executable inventories with hashes, extract NVRAM variables, and parse SPI flash descriptors. Use when analyzing firmware .bin/.rom/.fd/.cap files offline without requiring hardware access.

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and instructions for using Intel's chipsec framework. No executable scripts, no network calls, no credential access, and no code execution capabilities. The skill is purely instructional content describing how to perform static firmware analysis.

content.user_title: Analyze UEFI firmware for malware and vulnerabilities
content.value_statement: UEFI firmware attacks are stealthy and persistent. This skill uses Intel's chipsec framework to scan firmware dumps for known rootkits, detect vulnerabilities, and generate inventories of EFI modules. Analyze firmware safely offline without requiring hardware access.
actual_capabilities: Scan firmware dumps for known UEFI malware and rootkits (LoJax, ThinkPwn, HackingTeam, MosaicRegressor)
Generate EFI executable inventories with SHA256 hashes for baseline comparison
Decode firmware structure and extract individual EFI binaries
Extract NVRAM/UEFI variables from firmware images
Parse SPI flash descriptors to identify firmware regions
Compare firmware against known-good baselines to detect unauthorized changes
limitations: Static analysis only - cannot access live system SPI flash or perform kernel-level tests
Requires chipsec to be installed on the system (pip install chipsec)
Cannot analyze encrypted or compressed firmware without pre-processing
Does not perform live Secure Boot or SMM security checks

use_cases.title: Firmware threat research
use_cases.description: Analyze suspicious firmware for known implants and document findings for threat intelligence

use_cases.title: Compromise assessment
use_cases.description: Compare suspect firmware against known-good baselines to detect unauthorized modifications

use_cases.title: Update verification
use_cases.description: Verify firmware update integrity by comparing inventories before and after updates

prompt_templates.title: Quick malware scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Use chipsec to scan this firmware file for known UEFI malware and rootkits. Run: chipsec_main -i -n -m tools.uefi.scan_blocked -a <firmware_file>

prompt_templates.title: Generate inventory
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate an EFI executable inventory for this firmware: chipsec_main -i -n -m tools.uefi.scan_image -a generate <output.json> <firmware_file>

prompt_templates.title: Decode structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Decode the firmware structure to extract EFI binaries and NVRAM: chipsec_util -i -n uefi decode <firmware_file>

prompt_templates.title: Compare baselines
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare this firmware against the baseline inventory: chipsec_main -i -n -m tools.uefi.scan_image -a check <baseline.json> <firmware_file>

output_examples.input: Scan firmware.bin for known UEFI threats
output: Alternatively, if a threat is found:
This SMM vulnerability allows code execution at ring 0

best_practices: Run the blocklist scan first to quickly detect known threats before detailed analysis
Generate an EFI inventory for every firmware image to create baselines for future comparison
Always save output with redirection (tee) for documentation and incident response reports
anti_patterns: Do not analyze firmware from systems you do not own or have explicit authorization to analyze
Do not skip the format verification step (file, binwalk) before running chipsec
Do not use chipsec for live system analysis - this skill is for static analysis only

faq.question: What firmware formats are supported?
faq.answer: Supports .bin, .rom, .fd, .cap, .scap, .fv, and .flash formats for raw firmware dumps and SPI flash images.

faq.question: What are the hardware requirements?
faq.answer: No hardware access needed. This skill performs static analysis on firmware dump files using chipsec as a local tool.

faq.question: How does this integrate with other tools?
faq.answer: Works with ffind for firmware extraction and binwalk for pre-processing. Output can be cross-referenced with UEFITool for visual analysis.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. All analysis runs locally on your machine. No data is sent anywhere. The skill only reads firmware files you specify.

faq.question: Why did the scan fail with 'module not found'?
faq.answer: Verify chipsec installation with 'pip show chipsec'. The scan_blocked module may not be available in older chipsec versions.

faq.question: How is this different from live BIOS security checks?
faq.answer: This skill analyzes firmware dumps offline. Live checks require kernel drivers and hardware access. This static approach is safer and works on any dump file.
